item.title: What the Bankruptcy of Saks Means for You
item.description: Answers to this and other questions about the financial crisis in America’s biggest luxury department store.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman and Jacob Bernstein
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis/Reuters
item.media:description: Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the country’s most storied luxury department stores, has filed for bankruptcy protection.

item.title: Saks Files for Bankruptcy as Department Stores Fight for Survival
item.description: The parent company of Saks, Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman struggled with debt, designers and customers in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Vanessa Friedman and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis/Reuters
item.media:description: Saks Fifth Avenue in New York City was founded in 1924 as a jewel of American retail. The store stands across the street from Rockefeller Center.

item.title: Mark Carney Heads to Beijing to Discuss Canada-China Relations as U.S. Outlook Darkens
item.description: The prime minister is seeking new markets for Canadian goods and to mend relations with China after years of deep acrimony between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yoan Valat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada and his advisers have said that he is seeking a pragmatic thawing of Canada’s relationship with China.

item.title: China Announces Record Trade Surplus as Its Exports Flood World Markets
item.description: China’s surplus reached $1.19 trillion last year, a 20 percent increase from 2024, as Beijing kept the currency weak and pursued self-reliance to replace imports.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The production line at a car factory in Hangzhou, China, in October. Exports to the United States fell, but rose to much of the rest of the world.

item.title: Starlink Users in Iran Get Free Internet Access, Nonprofits Say
item.description: Under a near-total communications blackout, users of Elon Musk’s satellite service have gotten online without paying, organizations that work on tech issues said.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: The Iranian government has cracked down on protests like this one in Tehran last week with a communications blockade.

item.title: In a Risky Gambit, Trump Tries Brute Force to Lower Prices
item.description: To assuage cost-weary voters and combat inflation, the president has resorted to a mix of threats and punishments, targeting companies and policymakers alike.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: There is seemingly no lever that President Trump appears unwilling to pull, as he looks to ease the economic strains on voters now anxious about the state of the country.

item.title: Blowback Builds Over Criminal Investigation of Powell
item.description: Trump allies fear that the inquiry into the Fed chair could complicate the process of replacing him this year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Colby Smith, Glenn Thrush and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Global economic leaders have expressed concern about the credibility of the world’s most important economic institution after the Justice Department’s announcement of an investigation into the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Initial Obamacare Enrollment Drops by 1.4 Million as Expiring ACA Subsidies Drive Up Premiums
item.description: That number could increase significantly as more consumers are faced with higher bills brought on by expiring premium subsidies.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: An insurance sales office in Miami-Dade County in October.

item.title: What to know about the report.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Orsted Moves to Save Its U.S, Wind Farm Projects
item.description: Orsted’s C.E.O. says it plans to move quickly to complete a $6.2 billion wind farm off Rhode Island after a judge struck down President Trump’s bid to halt it.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Revolution Wind is expected to power 350,000 homes in Rhode Island and Connecticut.

item.title: CPI Report Shows Food Prices Rose Sharply in December
item.description: Beef, coffee and produce were among the items that surged in price, inflation data showed.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The increase in food prices could frustrate consumers who have been facing higher costs at the grocery store for years.

item.title: Gourmet Magazine Is Back, as Unsanctioned New Media
item.description: The defunct food publication is re-emerging as a newsletter, with new leadership and zero approval from its original owner.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: On Tuesday, Gourmet will be rebooted as an online newsletter on the platform Ghost.

item.title: JPMorgan Made Less Money Last Year, Facing Pressure on Multiple Fronts
item.description: The nation’s largest bank earned $57 billion in 2025, and Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, said “the benefits of deregulation” would help in the future.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: JPMorgan Chase, which recently moved into new headquarters in Manhattan, flagged several factors that prevented its earnings from growing faster.

item.title: The Powell Defense Grows
item.description: Former Federal Reserve chiefs, Republican senators and — perhaps most important, many bond investors — raised concerns about an investigation into the bank’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jay Powell, the Fed chair, has gained widespread support as a clash with the Trump administration escalates.

item.title: CPI Report Shows Inflation Remained Steady at 2.7% in December
item.description: Surging grocery prices were offset by lower increases for appliances and vehicles in the last such report before the Federal Reserve meets to debate interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Why haven’t tariffs had a bigger impact on prices?
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Goods often take weeks to reach U.S. ports, meaning the actual tariffs that companies paid rose more slowly than what the president announced throughout the year.

item.title: Global Central Bankers Rally Around Fed Chair Powell Amid Criminal Investigation
item.description: The defense comes after Jerome Powell pushed back on what he described as pressure by the Trump administration to cut interest rates in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Central bankers around the world signed a statement of support for the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, on Tuesday.

item.title: Delta Offers Optimistic Outlook as Travelers Continue to Splurge
item.description: Delta Air Lines said it was expecting profits to rise by around 20 percent in 2026 thanks to strong demand for premium tickets.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delta Air Lines has enjoyed financial success partly because it caters to travelers who are willing to spend a lot on luxurious seats and airport lounges.

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Riches Are Years Off, but Winners and Losers Will Emerge
item.description: Companies that already have operations in the country stand to benefit, but those that have profited from a standoff between Caracas and Washington could lose out.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Venezuela in 2020. Despite its massive oil reserves, Venezuela produces about 1 percent of the world’s oil.

item.title: Facing Political Pressure, Trump Seeks Answer to Rising Housing Costs
item.description: White House officials have explored a vast array of ideas as the president looks to unfurl a housing affordability plan at an economic conference this month.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Mike Belleme for The New York Times
item.media:description: Home prices have soared in recent years, climbing nearly 55 percent from the first quarter of 2020 to the third quarter of 2025.

item.title: ‘We Need to Be the News’: Inside Bari Weiss’s Bumpy Revamp at CBS
item.description: Her reimagining of “CBS Evening News” is under heavy scrutiny, and even became a punchline on her own network on Sunday at the Golden Globes.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Manhattan studios of CBS, where Bari Weiss has been making changes at “CBS Evening News” since becoming editor in chief in October.

item.title: ’Shrooms Lead the Pack in Psychedelic Medicine, but Rollout Is Bumpy
item.description: Psilocybin-assisted therapy is legal in three states, but access has so far been limited and expensive.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Bonny Koeber prepared a therapy room with sage before a patient arrived from New York for psilocybin therapy at Satya Therapeutics in Ashland, Ore.

item.title: Why China Is Suddenly Obsessed With American Poverty
item.description: State media, embracing the gaming phrase “kill line,” is asserting China’s political superiority over the United States, deflecting focus on China’s own economic challenges.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Doris Liou

item.title: Labor Secretary’s Aides Placed on Leave in Misconduct Investigation
item.description: The Labor Department is investigating a complaint alleging misconduct by Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, the secretary of labor, on Capitol Hill last year. The Labor Department’s watchdog is investigating allegations of professional misconduct involving the secretary.

item.title: A Top Fed Official Conveys Little Urgency for Immediate Rate Cuts
item.description: The Federal Reserve is likely to hold interest rates steady when it meets at the end of the month, keeping tensions high with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: John Williams, President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in October.

item.title: Trump’s Feel-My-Pain Economic Message
item.description: The president appears skeptical about Americans’ concerns. How will voters respond?
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Air Force One.

item.title: What to Know About the Criminal Investigation of Fed Chair Jerome Powell
item.description: The Justice Department’s probe into whether Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, lied about renovations to the central bank’s headquarters has raised alarms.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve building in Washington under construction in July.

item.title: David Mitchell, Who Led Fight on Drug Prices, Dies at 75
item.description: After receiving a diagnosis of terminal cancer, he used his experience in public relations to draw attention to the skyrocketing cost of medication.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Brian Stukes/Getty Images for Protect Our Care
item.media:description: David Mitchell at a news conference in Washington in 2022. His group, Patients for Affordable Drugs, is widely credited with the inclusion of an annual cap on medication prices in the Inflation Reduction Act.

item.title: Supreme Court Grapples With Louisiana Coastal Lawsuits Against Oil Companies
item.description: The justices heard arguments over whether oil companies sued by Louisiana could move the cases from state to federal court, a venue thought to be friendlier to corporate interests.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Chevron Oronite oil additives manufacturing facility, seen in 2008 in Plaquemines Parish, La.

item.title: Trump Administration Nears Trade Deal With Taiwan
item.description: The deal would cut tariffs and include a commitment from Taiwanese Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation, the island’s chip giant, to build more manufacturing plants in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation facility under construction in Phoenix. As part of the trade deal, the company would commit to building more semiconductor facilities in Arizona.

item.title: Paramount Threatens Board Fight Over Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: The announcement was the latest in a series of increasingly aggressive actions by Paramount to buy Warner Bros.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Warner Bros. studios in Burbank, Calif.

item.title: Fed Changes Course and Takes On Trump’s Political Fight
item.description: The Justice Department’s decision to open up a criminal investigation of Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, is a major escalation in the pressure campaign against the central bank to cut interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell is the first Federal Reserve chair to face a criminal investigation.

item.title: Stocks, Bonds and the Dollar Fluctuate on Threat to Fed Chair Powell
item.description: Stocks and U.S. Treasuries were relatively unchanged on Monday, a sign investors don’t see an immediate threat to the economy.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Eshe Nelson

item.title: The Potential Fallout From a Legal Attack on Powell
item.description: A criminal investigation into Jay Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, may be the most consequential attack yet on the central bank’s political independence.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jay Powell, the Fed chair, issued an uncharacteristically sharp response to the news that the Justice Department had opened a criminal investigation into him.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Under UK Investigation Over Grok’s Sexualized A.I. Images
item.description: A British regulator said it had started a formal investigation into Mr. Musk’s chatbot over the spread of illegal images.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grok’s prompt page on a phone. In recent weeks, the chatbot has posted sexualized photos of real people, including children, in response to user prompts.

item.title: Europe and China Take Step to Resolve Dispute on Electric Vehicles
item.description: The European Commission allowed carmakers to volunteer limits on their imports from China instead of paying tariffs, an arrangement that could help Volkswagen.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Leonhard Simon/Reuters
item.media:description: The Cupra Tavascan, an electric vehicle made by Volkswagen in China, at the Munich auto show in 2023.

item.title: Allegiant to Buy Sun Country Airlines in $1.5 Billion Deal
item.description: The combination of the two small, budget airlines comes as low-cost carriers have struggled with high costs and competition.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Tim Evans/Reuters
item.media:description: Both Allegiant and Sun Country focus on providing cheap flights to people traveling for fun or to visit friends and family.

item.title: Thiel Gives $3 Million to Group Seeking to Block California Wealth Tax
item.description: More large donations from wealthy Silicon Valley figures are expected as they try to marshal opposition to a proposed ballot measure that would impose a new tax on billionaires.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Getty
item.media:description: Peter Thiel donated $3 million to a committee opposing California’s proposed wealth tax, according to a new disclosure.

item.title: Malaysia and Indonesia Block Access to Grok Because of Sexually Explicit Content
item.description: Grok, the chatbot created by Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence company, has produced a flood of explicit images featuring real people in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prompt page for Grok, the A.I. chatbot made by xAI.

item.title: Podcasts Hit the Golden Globes: Nominees Include ‘Call Her Daddy’ and More
item.description: The annual awards show will anoint a best podcast for the first time this year, a sign of the industry’s increasing status in Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.category: Good Hang with Amy Poehler (Radio Program)
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jason Bateman, Will Arnett, Alex Cooper, Sean Hayes and Mel Robbins at a SiriusXM event in Los Angeles on Saturday.

item.title: How a Puzzling 401(k) Plan Changed One Woman’s Life
item.description: Eryn Schultz was an H-E-B grocery store leader with an M.B.A. A slow pivot toward a big career change began when she found her retirement plan wanting.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eryn Schultz helped her grocery store co-workers understand the company 401(k) when she worked at H-E-B in Texas. Now she is a full-time professional financial adviser.

item.title: How Gen Z Investors Went from Meme Stocks to Index Funds
item.description: Some Gen Z-ers first entered the markets during the pandemic’s meme stock craze. They have since become more patient investors.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Adamczyk
item.media:credit: Oliver Farshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mamadou-Hady Sow made risky, short-term bets in the meme stock craze. Now 23, he is more interested in maximizing his 401(k) and I.R.A. contributions every year.

item.title: Bird Flu Viruses Raise Mounting Concerns Among Scientists
item.description: Researchers are not just worried about the virus popping up on American farms. Other types are causing trouble around the world.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The milking parlor of a Wisconsin dairy farm. The Agriculture Department announced the first detection of bird flu in a herd in the state, the third time the virus had jumped from wildlife into dairy cattle last year.

item.title: $100 Billion to Revive Venezuela’s Energy Industry? Oil Executives Are Not So Sure
item.description: During a meeting at the White House, the industry leaders appeared wary of making long-term investments in the country.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Brian O’Keefe, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Niko Gallogly
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump takes questions from members of the news media during a meeting with oil and gas executives on Friday.

item.title: Popularity of ‘Heated Rivalry’ Has Surprised Even TV Executives
item.description: The show, streaming on HBO Max, doesn’t have one of the biggest audiences, but viewership grew very quickly in just a few weeks.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Sabrina Lantos/Crave, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Hudson Williams, left, and Connor Storrie as a pair of gay hockey players in “Heated Rivalry,” in an image released by Crave, the show’s Canadian producer.

item.title: The Boss Who Hates Sick Day Requests
item.description: Plus, the impossibility of being a middle manager.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Neon, an Indie Studio With an International Bent, Tops Globes Nominations
item.description: Neon scored more film nominations at the Golden Globes than any other studio this year with a slate of six non-English language films.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling

item.title: Volkswagen Suffers More Than Rivals From Auto Industry Woes
item.description: The German automaker’s sales in the United States plunged last year, hit by tariffs and the end of tax credits for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Jens Schlueter/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Electric vehicles at a Volkswagen plant in Dresden, Germany. The company is an extreme example of how difficult it has been for foreign automakers to cope in the U.S. car market.

item.title: Trump Wants 10% Cap on Credit Card Interest Rates, After Killing Other Fee Limits
item.description: The president revived a campaign promise he has not actively pursued since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Trump’s $100 Billion Venezuela Oil Plan Gets a Cool Reception
item.description: President Trump met with oil and gas executives on Friday in an effort to push them to invest money in Venezuela, a plan many of them are reluctant to embrace.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump during a meeting with energy executives at the White House on Friday. He wants the biggest U.S. and European oil companies to pour at least $100 billion into Venezuela.
